The region has Europe‚Äôs highest density of unicorns ‚Äî privately held companies valued at over $1bn. Despite accounting for only 4% of Europe‚Äôs population, the Nordics hosted 17% of the continent‚Äôs unicorns between 2013 and 2023.

The Nordics also possess one of Europe‚Äôs leading investment landscapes. The region is home to over 14,000 funded startups, which collectively raised $5.6bn in 2024,
Dealroom data. Sweden, Norway, Finland, and Denmark rank among Europe‚Äôs top 15 countries for VC investment, while Iceland sits in the top 50.
This thriving ecosystem has produced global giants like Spotify and Klarna. Now, TECH5 aims to uncover the next wave of tech titans.
TNW‚Äôs judges selected the five finalists based on their growth, impact, and future potential. Let‚Äôs meet them (listed in no particular order).

These businesses are the backbone of the European economy, representing 99% of all EU firms and over 100 million jobs. Yet they remain underserved by traditional banks, facing slow decision-making, rigid processes, and financial barriers that hinder growth.

is redefining pet care ‚Äî with insurance at its core. The fast-rising scaleup has a preventative focus that combines veterinary care, coaching for owners, e-commerce, and advice from vets to keep our furry companions healthy.

‚ÄúOur ambition is to become the European leader in pet insurance and preventive care ‚Äî then go global,‚Äù the company told TNW. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just covering medical costs; we‚Äôre improving pet health, extending lifespans, and giving owners peace of mind.‚Äù
The norm that Denmark‚Äôs

wants to foster is circularity. Its target for the transition is office furniture. The scaleup helps businesses cut their environmental impact by ditching single-use furniture for a circular, subscription-based service.
Founded in 2020 by former IKEA manager Anders Jepsen and Skype co-creator Jonas Kjellberg, NORNORM¬†is based in Copenhagen. In 2022, the company secured ‚Ç¨110
in a funding round led by growth equity firm Verdane.¬†Inter IKEA Development also contributed to the round.
Today, NORNORM is active in 17 countries and 59 cities. The company plans to bring its service to many more businesses ‚Äî and not only big brands.

‚ÄúReal impact comes from reaching the many, not the few, which is why we have designed an accessible and highly affordable solution that requires no upfront investment or long-term commitment,‚Äù NORNORM told TNW.
‚ÄúBy making circular office interiors both attractive and scalable, we are driving systemic change in the industry and proving that sustainability and business success go hand in hand.‚Äù
Diklev wants his home country to set a standard in the energy transition. ‚Äú

The Swedish scaleup has created a cloud-based collaboration platform that connects healthcare professionals, medical educators, and researchers. Its goal? Accelerating patient access to accurate diagnoses and effective treatments.

Collective Minds has high hopes for Sweden‚Äôs digital future. Alongside its talent, culture, and history of scaling big ideas, the scaleup emphasised the country‚Äôs focus on sustainability and impact-driven innovation ‚Äî which makes it ‚Äúan exciting place to build something meaningful.‚Äù

With the Nordic challengers joining the Benelux contenders in the TECH5 regional finals, the competition for the hottest scaleup in Europe is heating up. Next Monday, we unveil the five finalists from another rising region: DACH.

title: This Una smartwatch can be taken apart like LEGO and repaired at home
resume: It could be the last smartwatch you'll ever own...
author: Si√¥n Geschwindt
segments: Scottish startup Una aims to upend this take-make-waste cycle. The company‚Äôs sports smartwatch is built to be repaired. Users can easily swap, replace, and
¬†individual components like the screen, battery, and health sensors, extending the device‚Äôs lifespan.
‚ÄúCustomers are tired of replacing expensive tech every few years,‚Äù said Lewis Allison, Una‚Äôs founder. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre showing the industry there‚Äôs a better way.‚Äù

Una had a blockbuster launch on Kickstarter last week, signalling early demand for its repairable, upgradable smartwatch. The startup raised over ¬£200,000 in just 48 hours after its launch on the crowdfunding platform. That‚Äôs more than 20 times its initial fundraising goal of ¬£10,000.
Over 3,000 people have pre-ordered Una‚Äôs smartwatch. The first deliveries are due to begin in August 2025 to customers in the EU, UK,
The üíú of EU tech
The latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!

While sustainability is at its core, Una‚Äôs watch doesn‚Äôt compromise on high-tech features. The smartwatch uses dual-frequency GPS, improving the accuracy, reliability, and robustness of location data.
hese include a barometric altimeter for elevation changes, an accelerometer to track movement, and a magnetometer for orientation. It also measures heart rate and blood oxygen levels.
Powered by an ultra-efficient Cortex-M33 chip, the smartwatch offers up to 10 days of battery life. It charges via a regular USB-C cable.

Una runs on FreeRTOS, an open-source operating system for microelectronics. The company also offers add-on hardware and software ‚Äúkits‚Äù that allow users to build custom apps, create new hardware modules, and even write their own firmware.
Una departs from proprietary, closed-source devices like the Apple Watch and Garmin, which dominate the global smartwatch market,
$33bn last year.
The Edinburgh-based startup is one of a growing number of tech companies developing products that customers can fix and upgrade themselves. Other examples include Fairphone, which
that can be repaired at home using just a screwdriver and a video manual, and Framework, which builds modular laptops.
Una‚Äôs Kickstarter success follows a ¬£300,000 investment from SFC Capital in March. The company also won ¬£100,000 in the Scottish EDGE startup competition last year.
